lines.text: [first lines]
Now I want you to remember that no bastard ever won a war by dying for his country. He won it by making the other poor dumb bastard die for his country.
[Outmaneuvering Rommel]

[referring to Rommel's book, 'Infantry Attacks' or 'Infanterie greift an']
Rommel... you magnificent bastard, *I read your book*!
Fixed fortifications are monuments to the stupidity of man. If mountain ranges and oceans can be overcome, then anything built by man can be overcome.
The general would like to know if you will drink a toast with him.
Thank the general and tell him I have no desire to drink with him or any other Russian son of a bitch.

[Nervous]
I can't tell him that!
Tell him, every word.

[In Russian]
He says he will not drink with you or any Russian son of a bitch.

[In Russian]
Tell him he is a son of a bitch, too. Now!

[Very nervous]
He says he thinks you are a son of a bitch, too.

[laughing]
All right. All right, tell him I'll drink to that; one son of a bitch to another.

Now there's another thing I want you to remember. I don't want to get any messages saying that "we are holding our position." We're not holding anything. Let the Hun do that. We are advancing constantly and we're not interested in holding onto anything except the enemy. We're going to hold onto him by the nose and we're going to kick him in the ass. We're going to kick the hell out of him all the time and we're going to go through him like crap through a goose!
[about his pistol grips]
They're ivory. Only a pimp from a cheap New Orleans whorehouse would carry a pearl-handled pistol.
[last lines]
that all glory is fleeting.
General McAuliffe refused a German surrender demand. You know what he said?
What?
"Nuts!"

[laughing]
Keep them moving, colonel. A man that eloquent has to be saved.

Thirty years from now, when you're sitting around your fireside with your grandson on your knee and he asks you, "What did you do in the great World War II," you won't have to say, "Well... I shoveled shit in Louisiana."
Up bright and early, General? Uh, breakfast?
Am I to understand that my officers have already finished eating?
Uh, well, we're open from six to eight. Most of the men are just coming in now.
[Indicates two soldiers who enter the mess hall]
Please inform these men that the mess hall is closed.
But sir, it's only a quarter 'til eight.
From now on, you will open at six, and no man will be admitted after six-fifteen. Where are your leggings?
Leggings? Oh hell, General sir, I'm a cook.
You're a soldier. Twenty dollar fine.
[two more soldiers enter the mess hall. Patton looks them over]
Gentlemen, from this moment, any soldier without leggings, without a helmet, without a tie, any man with unshined shoes or a soiled uniform... is going to be skinned.
We're gonna keep fighting. Is that CLEAR? We're gonna attack all night, we're gonna attack tomorrow morning. If we are not VICTORIOUS, let no man come back alive!
You know General, sometimes the men don't know when you're acting.
It's not important for them to know. It's only important for me to know.
I was interested to see a Bible by your bed. You actually find time to read it?
I sure do. Every goddamn day.
What are you doing there, soldier?
Trying to get some sleep, sir.
Well, get back down there, son. You're the only son of a bitch in this headquarters who knows what he's trying to do.
What is this activity near Coulances?
Enemy armored forces driving through our defenses at Lessay.
[reading telegram]
"American tanks moving rapidly, slicing through to the rear areas."
This sounds like Patton, Field Marshall.
Patton is in England.
Do we know this?
The landing in Normandy is merely a diversionary maneuver. The real invasion will come at Calais and Patton will lead it. The Fuehrer says that the Fifteenth Army is not to be moved to Normandy.
Those men are sitting on the beach at Calais throwing rocks at each other while our men are being slaughtered in Normandy.

[firmly]
The Fifteenth Army is waiting for Patton at Calais and he will land there.
You seem perfectly willing to accept this nonsense, Jodl. Why?

[chuckles]
Because I am not prepared to dispute the Fuehrer.
Now, an army is a team - it lives, eats, sleeps, fights as a team. This individuality stuff is a bunch of crap.
There's one big difference between you and me, George. I do this job because I've been trained to do it. You do it because you LOVE it.
I've always felt that I was destined for some great achievement, what I don't know.
Yes, sir.
The last great opportunity of a lifetime - an entire world at war, and I'm left out of it? God will not permit this to happen! I will be allowed to fulfill my destiny! His will be done.
In about fifteen minutes, we're going to start turning these boys into fanatics - razors. They'll lose their fear of the Germans. I only hope to God they never lose their fear of me.
Where ya goin', General?
Berlin. I'm going to personally shoot that paper-hangin' sonofabitch.
What's the matter with you?
I... I guess I... I can't take it sir.
What did you say?
It's my nerves, sir. I... I... I just can't stand the shelling anymore.
Your *nerves*? Well, hell, you're just a God-damned coward.
[Soldier starts sniveling]
[Slaps him, once forehanded, then backhanded on the rebound]
Shut up! I won't have a yellow bastard sitting here *crying* in front of these brave men who have been wounded in battle!
[Soldier snivels some more, and Patton swings a vicious forehand slap, knocking his helmet away]
*Shut up!*
[to the doctors]
Don't admit this yellow bastard. There's nothing wrong with him. I won't have sons-of-bitches who are afraid to fight *stinking up this place of honor!*
[to soldier]

You're going back to the front, my friend. You may get shot, and you may get killed, but you're going up to the fighting. Either that, or I'm going to stand you up in front of a firing squad. I ought to shoot you myself, you god-damned... bastard! Get him out of here!
[pulls his service automatic. At that, the doctors leap forward and hustle the soldier out of the tent. Patton keeps shouting at the soldier's back]
Take him up to the front! You hear me? You God-damned coward!
[Takes deep breath]
I won't have cowards in my army.
In ten days I'll have a war on with those Communist bastards, and I'll make it look like THEIR fault.
[Visiting an ancient battlefield]

The Carthaginians defending the city were attacked by three Roman legions. The Carthaginians were proud and brave but they couldn't hold. They were massacred. Arab women stripped them of their tunics and their swords and lances. The soldiers lay naked in the sun. Two thousand years ago. I was here.
In 15 minutes, we meet with the Fuhrer. He will want to know how you intend to deal with Patton's forces.
I will attack and annihilate him...!
[long pause]
...before he does the same to me.

Almighty and most merciful Father, we humbly beseech Thee of Thy great goodness to restrain this immoderate weather with which we have had to contend. Grant us fair weather for battle. Graciously harken to us as solders who call upon Thee that, armed with Thy power, we may advance from victory to victory, and crush the oppression and wickedness of our enemies, and establish Thy justice among men and nations. AMEN.
I love it. God help me I do love it so. I love it more than my life.
God, how I hate the twentieth century.

[to his dog, named after William the Conqueror, after it is panicked by a much smaller dog]
Your name isn't William, it's Willy!
We've been told about these wonder weapons the Germans were working on - long range rockets, push button bombing, weapons that don't need soldiers...

"Wonder weapons"? By God, I don't see the wonder in them. Killing without heroics? Nothing is glorified? Nothing is reaffirmed? No heroes, no cowards, no troops, no generals. Only those who are left alive, and those who are left... dead. I'm glad I won't live to see it.

Men, all this stuff you've heard about America not wanting to fight, wanting to stay out of the war, is a lot of horse dung. Americans traditionally love to fight. All real Americans love the sting of battle. When you were kids, you all admired the champion marble shooter, the fastest runner, big league ball players, the toughest boxers. Americans love a winner and will not tolerate a loser. Americans play to win all the time. I wouldn't give a hoot in hell for a man who lost and laughed. That's why Americans have never lost, and will never lose a war... because the very thought of losing is hateful to Americans.
The Nazis are the enemy. Wade into them. Spill *their* blood. Shoot *them* in the belly.
We're not just going to shoot the bastards, we're going to cut out their living guts and use them to grease the treads on our tanks. We're going to murder those lousy Hun bastards by the bushel.
[as the British parade into Messina]
Don't smirk, Patton. I shan't kiss you.
lines.character: Field Marshal Sir Bernard Law Montgomery

lines.text: Pity. I shaved very close this morning in preparation for getting smacked by you.
You can afford to be an optimist. I can't.
This is a barracks; it's not a bordello.
When you put your hand into a bunch of goo that a moment before was your best friend's face, you'll know what to do.
the last bullet of the last battle of the last war.

You want to know why this outfit got the hell kicked out of it? A blind man could spot it. They don't act like soldiers; they don't look like soldiers; why should they be expected to fight like soldiers?
When we took Palermo they called me a hero, said I was the greatest general since Stonewall Jackson.

[looking at a newspaper and chuckling]
And now they draw cartoons about you.
I can't wear my helmet and use a stethoscope.
Well, then cut two holes in your helmet and see that you can.
They haven't spotted our positions yet.
They will get some education in about 10 seconds when they get a dose of our artillery fire.

[apologizing to his troops after the "slapping" incident]
I can assure you that I had no intention of being either harsh or cruel in my treatment of the... soldier in question. My sole purpose was to try to restore in him some sense of appreciation of his obligations as a man and as a soldier. "If one could shame a coward," I felt, "one might help him to regain his self-respect." This was on my mind. Now, I freely admit that my method was wrong, but I hope you can understand my motive. And that you will accept this explanation... and this... apology.
What we really need is... someone tough enough to really pull this outfit together.
Patton?
Possibly.

[with a smile]
God help us!

[Morroccan Minister speaking to Patton,in presenting award, immediately after placing medal around Patton's neck]
The lions in their dens tremble at his approach.

[inside the German bunker]
Sir, the Americans have taken Palermo!
Damn!

[after pulling up to Monty's command post]
Sir, Patton's taken Palermo!
Damn!
lines.character: Field Marshal Sir Bernard Law Montgomery

lines.text: You know, George, you'd have made a great Marshal for Napoleon, if you'd lived in the 18th Century.
Oh, but I did, Sir Alex, I did.
What silly son of a bitch is in charge of this operation?
I don't know, but they oughta hang him.

[Codman is handed a letter while riding through the newly liberated Palermo]
This is from from General Alexander, sir, reminding you that you are not to take Palermo.
Send him a message, Cod. Ask him if he wants me to give it back.
The absence of war will destroy him.

This is where it pays off, the training and the discipline. No other outfit in the world could pull out of a winter battle, move a hundred miles, go into a major attack with no rest, no sleep, no hot food. God... God, I'm proud of these men!

[on the Battle of Kasserine Pass]
The Americans were under the command of British General Anderson.
[smiles broadly]
American soldiers and British generals - the worst of both worlds!

[curtly]
May I remind you that *Montgomery* is British?
[German military personnel are frantically burning papers in a disordered headquarters as they prepare to retreat]
[Subtitle]
Hurry, Steiger. I want everything destroyed. Papers, maps, everything!

[Subtitle]
Everything will be destroyed, General, that I can promise you.
The pure warrior... a magnificent anachronism.
The bilious bastards who wrote that stuff about individuality for the Saturday Evening Post don't know anything more about real battle than they do about fornicating.

[Patton is apologizing to the troops after the slapping incident]
I thought I would stand here like this so you could see if I was really as big a son of a bitch as you think I am.

You know, Dick, if I had my way, I'd meet Rommel face to face; him in his tank and me in mine. We'd meet out there somewhere... salute each other, maybe drink a toast, then we'd button up and do battle. The winner would decide the outcome of the entire war.
[Vice-Marshal Arthur Coningham and General Patton are discussing the lack of supporting air cover the British have been providing for American troops]
I promise you one thing, General. You will see no more German planes.
[Moments later two German planes fly by overhead and begin to attack the compound, part of the ceiling in the room the two are in collapses as they scramble to take cover underneath a table]
You were discussing, uh, air supremacy, Sir Arthur?
We're going to have to fight the Russians eventually anyway. It might as well be now while we've already got the army here to do it.

[to Patton, after the slapping incident got him relieved of command of the Seventh Army]
One little dogface... one measly slap... that's what done it.

[ruefully]
Ah, George... I wish I'd *kissed* the son-of-a bitch.
There goes old blood-and-guts.
Yeah, our blood, his guts.
Long-range rockets, push-button bombing weapons that don't need soldiers. What's your take on that?

Wonder weapons? My God, I don't see the wonder in them. Killing without heroics. Nothing is glorified, nothing is reaffirmed. No heroes, no cowards, no troops. No generals. Only those that are left alive and those that are left... dead.
Look at that, gentlemen. Compared to war, all other forms of human endeavor shrink to insignificance.
Shall I call the artist back sir?
To hell with it. Nobody wants to see a picture of me, I'm mad! Didn't you know that?
This is the end... the end.
"Despicable". That's the first time anyone's ever applied that word to me.
I don't know why, but the image of a bullet coming straight for my nose was more horrifying than anything else.
Well, I can understand that, George, it's such a handsome nose.
I'm not going to subsidize cowardice.
G2 also reports that Hitler probably retained Rommel in Berlin because things were going badly for the Afrika Korps. He didn't want his favorite general to lose face.
Well, I'm my favorite General. I don't want to be told that some second stringer is up against me; Then *I* lose face.
[winks]

[Bradley frowns as Patton pins on his new stars]
What's the matter, Brad? I've been nominated by the president.
I know... but it doesn't become official until it's been approved by the Senate.
Well, they have their schedule and I have mine.

[smiles wryly]
George, I think if you were named Admiral of the Turkish navy, your aides could dip into their haversacks and come up with the appropriate badges of rank. Anyway, congratulations, George...
[extends his hand, then pulls it back]
*premature* congratulations.
[shakes Patton's hand]

[explaining Patton's attitude toward war]
Sir, do you not see?
What?
Don Quixote battles six merchants from Toledo and saves Dulcinea's virtue!
Who the devil is Dulcinea?

[as he watches Moroccan soldiers taking part in a parade]
Magnificent! I wish our troops looked that good!

[the Chaplain has delivered a weather prayer, and the weather has cleared]
Go find me that Chaplain!... He stands in good with the Lord, and I want to decorate him!

[Upon entering his hotel room in London]
Who picked out this cathouse?
I believe it was General Smith.
He did it to spite me, that son of a bitch.
[General Bidell Smith walks in]
I want a prayer... A weather prayer.
A weather prayer, sir?
Yes... Let's see if we can't get God helping us with this thing.
It'll take a pretty thick rug for that kind of prayer.
I don't care if it takes a flying carpet.
